This IRM supersedes IRM 13.1.6 dated October 17, 2014.
Taxpayer Advocate Service employees
Signed by Bonnie Fuentes, Executive Director Case Advocacy, Intake and Technical Support.
Table of Contents

) Purpose: This IRM section provides communication guidance and outlines communication requirements for Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS) and advocating to resolve taxpayer issues. It is also designed to encourage TAS employees to consider issues from the taxpayer‚Äôs perspective, and act with empathy when communicating with the taxpayer or representative as they to resolve the taxpayer‚Äôs problem. (
) Audience: These procedures apply to all TAS employees. (
) Policy Owner: The Executive Director Case Advocacy, Intake and Technical Support (EDCA-ITS), who reports to the Deputy National Taxpayer Advocate (DNTA). (
) Program Owner: The Director, Technical Analysis and Guidance, who to the EDCA-ITS. (

) To advocate effectively, TAS employees must be excellent communicators need to know how to use both written and oral communications to convey an attitude of advocacy and service. Employee communications must be profes- sional and at the same time encourage conÔ¨Ådence in the TAS organization its representatives. Communications must be clear, concise, and informative. Taxpayers need to know we hear them, and want to help resolve their problems in a fair and equitable manner. TAS employees have an obligation educate taxpayers about their rights, while also ensuring these rights are considered and protected. Refer to IRM
, Communication Skills and Requirements, for additional guidance. (

) Taxpayers have the right to know what they need to do to comply with the laws. They are entitled to clear explanations of the laws and IRS procedures all tax forms, instructions, publications, notices, and correspondence. They have the right to be informed of IRS decisions about their tax account, and to receive clear explanations of the outcomes. (

) Taxpayers and representatives have the right to receive prompt, courteous, and professional assistance in their dealings with the IRS, to be spoken to in way they can easily understand, to receive clear and easily understandable communications, and to have a means to Ô¨Åle complaints about inadequate service. (
) Pursuant to IRC
(c), the Office of the Taxpayer Advocate (known as shall assist taxpayers to resolve problems with the IRS. (
) TAS employees are responsible for communicating with taxpayers and repre- sentatives in a prompt, courteous and professional manner. (
) TAS employees will strive to empathize with the taxpayer during these nications and will speak to the taxpayer in a way that the taxpayer can easily understand. (
) TAS managers are responsible for ensuring employees within their purview following TAS communication policies. (
) Internal Revenue Manual

In every initial contact with the taxpayer employees are required to furnish the
a. Last Name; b. Job title; c. Office address; d. Office telephone number; e. Tour of duty; f. IRS HSPD-
(Smart ID)

-digit Personal IdentiÔ¨Åcation (PID) g. SpeciÔ¨Åc, sincere apology; h. Notice of acceptance in TAS; i. TAS statement of independence; j. Explanation of TAS conÔ¨Ådentiality; and k. An estimated completion date (ECD) and next contact date (NCD). (
) The purpose of the contact should be to: a. Restate and clarify any questions regarding the problem identiÔ¨Åed on Form

or correspondence; b. Gain an understanding of the taxpayer‚Äôs needs and circumstances rounding the taxpayer‚Äôs situation; c. Request any additional information needed; d. Discuss the proposed remedy or solution to the problem; and e. Explain what actions TAS will take to resolve the issue. (
) TAS employees must always verify the taxpayer‚Äôs identity per IRM
, Authorized Disclosures, before discussing any information protected under IRC
) Check Command Code (CC) CFINK for any authorized representatives. If valid Power of Attorney (POA) is present, TAS must contact the POA. Addi- tional information can be found in IRM
, Third party Designee Authentication. TAS employees need to remember, taxpayers have the retain representation; See IRC
)(I). Before a TAS employee takes action that could compromise the taxpayer‚Äôs representation, extreme care caution must be taken to protect this right. (

) If the taxpayer initiated the TAS case, TAS employees need to contact the taxpayer to advise of the presence of a POA, and TAS‚Äôs requirement to with their representative unless the authorization is revoked by the the representative has withdrawn from representation). Instructions for an authorization can be found at the toolkit for Power of Attorney/Third Authorizations under the IRM Supplements tab on SERP. Note: It is vitally important for the POA to know the taxpayer has spoken to directly. Taxpayers may not understand the law, the consequences of actions, or may react inappropriately due to a fear of enforcement (

) If the taxpayer‚Äôs issue relates to payments or a math error on an original return, research to determine if the taxpayer checked the box authorizing party contact. If it is still within one year of the due date for the related contact the third party designee. Refer to IRM
, Third Party Authentication, for information on what can be discussed. (

) Employees will not interrupt their calls and conversations with taxpayers, parties or other IRS employees to take an incoming call on their personal phones. This includes incoming and outgoing phone media, such as text messages and emails. All personal cell phones should be silenced to avoid distractions and disturbances during working hours. Internal Revenue Manual

If the taxpayer initiated the TAS case, TAS employees need to contact the taxpayer to advise of the presence of a POA, and TAS‚Äôs requirement to work with their representative unless the authorization is revoked by the taxpayer (or the representative has withdrawn from representation). Instructions for revoking an authorization can be found at the toolkit for Power of Attorney/Third Party Authorizations under the IRM Supplements tab on SERP.

If the taxpayer‚Äôs issue relates to payments or a math error on an original return, research to determine if the taxpayer checked the box authorizing third party contact. If it is still within one year of the due date for the related return, contact the third party designee. Refer to IRM

, Third Party Designee Authentication, for information on what can be discussed. Employees will not interrupt their calls and conversations with taxpayers, third parties or other IRS employees to take an incoming call on their personal cell phones. This includes incoming and outgoing phone media, such as text
13.1 Taxpayer Advocate Case Procedures

) In all communications with taxpayers we must be aware of how our interac- tions can either encourage or discourage a taxpayer‚Äôs willingness to comply in tax matters. A taxpayer who has an opportunity to ask questions seek guidance, is going to be far more likely to do what is necessary to resolve a tax compliance issue. Therefore, TAS employees need to listen be ready to respond to a taxpayer‚Äôs speciÔ¨Åc questions and address the er‚Äôs concerns in a conÔ¨Ådent and professional manner. (

) Observe the following for effective communication with the taxpayer: a. Be empathetic; listen to the taxpayer‚Äôs concerns and consider how might feel if you were in the same situation; b. Always be polite; c. Emphasize the positive, understate the negative; d. Be conversational, do not lecture; e. Don‚Äôt make a taxpayer feel ignorant or troublesome; f. Don‚Äôt blame or criticize the taxpayer; g. Be considerate, even when the taxpayer may be wrong or made a mistake; and h. Acknowledge the taxpayer‚Äôs feelings; Is the taxpayer frustrated, angry, scared? (

) TAS employees need to consider how the situation may be adversely impacting the taxpayer, either emotionally or Ô¨Ånancially. Often this is the Ô¨Årst such interaction the taxpayer has had with the Service, and may be unsure what steps should be taken. The taxpayer may not understand what, if anything, has been done wrong. TAS employees need to be aware of the increased anxiety these issues may be causing, and need to know how to the taxpayer at ease.

Be empathetic; listen to the taxpayer‚Äôs concerns and consider how you might feel if you were in the same situation; Always be polite; Emphasize the positive, understate the negative; Be conversational, do not lecture; Don‚Äôt make a taxpayer feel ignorant or troublesome; Don‚Äôt blame or criticize the taxpayer; Be considerate, even when the taxpayer may be wrong or made a mistake; and Acknowledge the taxpayer‚Äôs feelings; Is the taxpayer frustrated, angry, scared? employees need to consider how the situation may be adversely

TAS employees need to consider how the situation may be adversely impacting the taxpayer, either emotionally or Ô¨Ånancially. Often this is the Ô¨Årst such interaction the taxpayer has had with the Service, and may be unsure of what steps should be taken. The taxpayer may not understand what, if anything, has been done wrong. TAS employees need to be aware of the increased anxiety these issues may be causing, and need to know how to put the taxpayer at ease.

For Example: ‚ÄúWe have several options available to resolve your tax situation. I know working with the IRS is very stressful, but I am here to help. Please come me if you have any questions or concerns. I am here to advocate for you, and to ensure you understand your rights as a taxpayer.‚Äù

a problem: a. Listen carefully to what the taxpayer is saying; b. Step into the taxpayer‚Äôs shoes, hear yourself as the taxpayer hears c. Speak slowly, distinctly, and enunciate your words clearly; d. Restate the taxpayer‚Äôs issue in your own words, and ask questions to ensure complete understanding; and e. Give the taxpayer an opportunity to ask questions. For a taxpayer unable to speak English, or for those with limited English ciency, consider use of the Language Line Services
Over the Phone

) TAS employees who are able to meet a taxpayer face to face have a opportunity to inÔ¨Çuence the taxpayer‚Äôs opinion of our organization. The the taxpayer leaves with can greatly inÔ¨Çuence not only their own opinion employees and our organization, but also the opinions of other individuals whom the taxpayer may share their experience. Because of this, we need be conscious of how we present ourselves. (

) When meeting a taxpayer face to face, there are several important things keep in mind: a. Greet the taxpayer warmly, professionally, and try to put the taxpayer ease; b. Maintain good body language (don‚Äôt act bored, disinterested, or c. Be conscious of facial expressions, tone of voice, volume and pitch; d. Dress professionally. (
) Always verify the taxpayer‚Äôs identity per IRM
, Authorized sures, before discussing any tax information protected under IRC

) While the majority of contacts will be in person or by telephone, there are times when written communication is necessary to: a. Send forms, transcripts, or other necessary information; b. ConÔ¨Årm issues agreed upon with the taxpayer; or c. Meet procedural or statutory requirements. (

) An effective business letter has strength and sincerity which is achieved through proper wording and tone. Effective business writing maintains a fessional attitude, but has a courteous tone that is still: ‚Ä¢ Polite; ‚Ä¢ Friendly; ‚Ä¢ Sincere; ‚Ä¢ Respectful; ‚Ä¢ Empathetic; and ‚Ä¢ Inclusive. (

) Letters need to clearly state what will happen next: a. Let the taxpayer know what they need to do (e.g., sign and return a form); b. Tell the taxpayer what they can expect (e.g., when an item will be a refund issued); and c. Explain what you will do (e.g., monitor their account, follow up with another function). (
) To improve the likelihood the taxpayer can understand the information and be able to follow your instructions, you need to make your message direct, clear, and complete:
Always verify the taxpayer‚Äôs identity per IRM 13.1.16.4.1.1, Authorized sures, before discussing any tax information protected under IRC 6103.

Letters need to clearly state what will happen next: a. Let the taxpayer know what they need to do (e.g., sign and return a form); b. Tell the taxpayer what they can expect (e.g., when an item will be a refund issued); and c. Explain what you will do (e.g., monitor their account, follow up with another function). 6 13.1 Taxpayer Advocate Case Procedures DIRECT 1. Always begin with an explanation of why you are writing the letter. Example: I‚Äôm writing in response to your corre- spondence dated (Month-DD-YYYY), referred to our office by . Your inquiry expressed concern regarding (List each issue brieÔ¨Çy in the same order as the taxpayer‚Äôs inquiry). CLEAR 1. Respond to each issue the taxpayer has raised in the order it is listed in the introductory paragraph; 2. Use a separate paragraph for each issue; 3. Write as you would speak; 4. Provide the taxpayer with the answer, then explain the rationale; 5. Use active voice, rather than passive voice; Example of Passive voice: My office is respon- sible for reviewing and monitoring correspondence, Example of Active voice: My office reviews and monitors correspondence; 6. Create a positive tone; Example of Negative Tone: Don‚Äôt hesitate to call me if you have questions, Example of Positive Tone: Please call me if you have questions; and 7. Use bullets, lists or headings when presenting complex or technical information. COMPLETE 1. The message should include all necessary infor- mation;2.Youcan achieve brevity in content by omitting needless words; Examples:Insteadof: .................. .................. .................. Use in order to................................................................to for the purpose of ..................................................for enclosed you will Ô¨Ånd...............................enclosed is 3. Write so the reader can understand your letter the Ô¨Årst time it is read; 4. Avoid using specialized terms; Examples:Insteadof ......................................................... Use accordingly........................................ ....................so demonstrate........................... ...........................show pursuant to .................. .................. .................. under 5. Be speciÔ¨Åc, and use concrete concepts, rather than vague or abstract terms; Example of vague : We will process your applica- tion shortly. Example of speciÔ¨Åc: We will process your applica- tion by MM/DD/YYYY.

In general, TAS should not communicate with a taxpayer by email, and TAS can never use email to communicate with a taxpayer about the speciÔ¨Åcs of a case; See IRM
, E-Mail Restrictions and IRM
,Secure Messaging & Encryption.

) In only limited circumstances is it permissible for TAS employees to communi- cate with the taxpayer using email (e.g., to forward blank forms or publications, no phone number provided, or repeated attempts to contact the taxpayer have failed).

These communications must never include sensitive but unclassiÔ¨Åed (SBU) information. TAS employees should use language similar to the following, ‚ÄúOur records reÔ¨Çect you contacted us for information or assistance. We have been unable to reach you. Due to security concerns, the IRS does not generally correspond with the public through email. If you would like to contact us, please call XXX
XXX
XXXX.‚Äù
Caution: Before using email to communicate with a taxpayer in such a limited cumstance, a TAS employee must consult with his or her manager.
TAS employees must never use a personal email account to conduct official business of the government; See IRM

, Emails with Personal Accounts. TAS has speciÔ¨Åc requirements which need to be incorporated into letters by our employees, including a requirement to use TAS letterhead. ‚ÄúQuick notes‚Äù are not acceptable. If sending a letter other than a TAS pattern letter, include all required TAS information. Approved TAS letterhead and pattern letters can be found on the TAS under Case Advocate and Intake Advocate Pattern Letters (English and Spanish). TAS letters can also be generated using the Integrated Technologies (IAT) letter tool. TAS correspondence must be prepared in accordance with IRM

, The IRS Correspondence Manual. TAS pattern letters are available for both case advocates and intake advocates, and differ slightly. Be sure to use the appropriate letter TAS pattern letters have been developed to include speciÔ¨Åc mandatory statements and explanations on certain issues. All TAS letters must include the TAS logo, office name and address, TAS ployee‚Äôs name, telephone number, office hours, and
-digit Smart ID number. The independence statement must be included in all TAS letters as part of TAS letterhead. Refer to IRM
, Inform Taxpayer of Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS) Independence.
(11-23-2020) TAS Letter Requirements and Pattern Letters
Taxpayer Advocate Case (
) TAS letters must follow IRS standards for correspondence formats and guide- lines as outlined in IRM
, Outgoing Correspondence. (
) Before initiating correspondence, check CC CFINK to ensure authorized sentatives receive copies of all TAS correspondence. Refer to IRM Third Party Designee Authentication. (
) Correspondence should be directed to the taxpayer and a copy sent to the payer‚Äôs representative, if applicable. Exception: See IRM
, Taxpayer Representation, for information and guidance on bypassing a representative. (

) It is mandatory to document TAMIS if a TAS letter is issued. If a Spanish is sent its content must be copied and summarized on the TAMIS history screen. Note: If using a TAS pattern letter, ensure all Ô¨Åll-in content is entered and reads accurately. (
) Communications to internal customers (within TAS or IRS) and other non related stakeholders is covered in IRM
, Internal and External Communications. (
) As of March
, IRM

, Privacy and Information Protection, Policy, was revised to incorporate reference to the Social Security Number Number Elimination and Reduction (SSN-ER) Program. Implementation requires the and elimination of all unnecessary use of SSNs. TAS has expanded this guidance to include all unnecessary use of Taxpayer IdentiÔ¨Åcation Numbers (TINs), not just SSNs. However, TAS has established a necessary and legitimate need to include SSNs, Individual Taxpayer IdentiÔ¨Åcation Numbers (ITINs), Employer IdentiÔ¨Åcation Numbers (EINs) within TAMIS. Most correspondence generated by TAS was determined to not require inclusion of a TIN. (

) TAS employees must not use a TIN on taxpayer correspondence unless the employee needs to identify the account to the recipient. If the TIN must be included, TAS will use only the last two digits whenever possible. There may be times when use of the full TIN is necessary, but this should be decided on case-by-case basis, and only after consultation with management. Be sure to document the conversation on TAMIS. (
) TAS has updated the pattern letters available through the TAS website to remove space for a TIN. (
) For more information, refer to the SSN Elimination and Reduction, Management site. (
) In an emergency situation where mail, fax, or in person communication may not be possible or is hindered (such as social distancing due to COVID-
), TAS can implement temporary guidance for the use of email through an Internal Guidance Memorandum (IGM). Ability Note: These memorandums will be posted at TAS Interim Guidance website.

TAS letters must follow IRS standards for correspondence formats and lines as outlined in IRM 21.3.3.4.17, Outgoing Correspondence.
Exception: See IRM 13.1.23, Taxpayer Representation, for information and guidance on bypassing a representative.
It is mandatory to document TAMIS if a TAS letter is issued. If a Spanish letter is sent its content must be copied and summarized on the TAMIS history

) TAS employees are required to offer a meaningful apology to each taxpayer. We need to acknowledge delays, miscommunications, processing errors, or anything else that may have contributed to the taxpayer‚Äôs problem. Just TAS is sorry for any inconvenience is not a sincere apology. Listed below are few examples of appropriate apologies: a. First, let me apologize for any (actions taken/delays) that may have added to your frustration. In reviewing your (Ô¨Åle/correspondence/ situation), it appears the Internal Revenue Service could, and should, have done a better job explaining your rights and the options available you. b. I regret that your contact with some Internal Revenue Service tives has left you with an unfavorable impression. I assure you the Taxpayer Advocate Service is committed to ensuring the IRS its responsibility to provide courteous, quality service to all taxpayers. c. I regret that the process of reaching a Ô¨Ånal tax determination was confusing or difficult for you. It is TAS‚Äôs mission to provide top quality service while helping you understand and meet your tax obligations. Note: Since each TAS apology should reference speciÔ¨Åcs of the taxpay- er‚Äôs issue, use of a generic apology is not appropriate. TAS employees should adjust the examples above to meet the needs and speciÔ¨Åcs of the taxpayer‚Äôs issue. (
) To increase the public‚Äôs awareness of and access to TAS, Congress that local directories list a telephone number for the Local Taxpayer (LTA) office. (
) Each LTA is responsible for verifying the publication of their respective TAS telephone numbers in their local directories. Refer to IRM
, Policy, for guidance when numbers are not listed. (

) The telephone numbers for each local TAS office will be listed immediately after the National Taxpayer Advocate (NTA) toll-free number, This will give taxpayers the option of toll-free services through the NTA or access to the local TAS office, where they may incur charges. (

) The following are established guidelines for incoming TAS telephone calls: a. LTAs will designate a member or members of their staff to answer telephone calls; b. LTAs may forward telephone calls to voice mail/answering machines for short periods of time if no one is available to answer the telephone; c. There shall be no instances when all calls to the LTA office are routed voice mail/answering machines as normal office procedure. (

) LTAs will use the following standardized voice mail message: You have reached the Taxpayer Advocate Service office located in (city/state). offers free, independent, and conÔ¨Ådential assistance to taxpayers experiencing a hardship, and taxpayers unable to resolve their tax problems through previous munications with the Internal Revenue Service. For general IRS tax questions and information, you should call

The Taxpayer Advocate Service operates independently of other IRS offices and reports directly to Congress through the National Taxpayer Advocate. Our business hours are from (provide office hours), Monday through Friday. Internal Revenue Manual

First, let me apologize for any (actions taken/delays) that may have added to your frustration. In reviewing your (Ô¨Åle/correspondence/ situation), it appears the Internal Revenue Service could, and should, have done a better job explaining your rights and the options available to you. I regret that your contact with some Internal Revenue Service representa

tives has left you with an unfavorable impression. I assure you the Taxpayer Advocate Service is committed to ensuring the IRS understands its responsibility to provide courteous, quality service to all taxpayers. I regret that the process of reaching a Ô¨Ånal tax determination was confusing or difficult for you. ) Each LTA is responsible for verifying the publication of their respective telephone numbers in their local directories. Refer to IRM
, Policy, for guidance when numbers are not listed. (

) The telephone numbers for each local TAS office will be listed after the National Taxpayer Advocate (NTA) toll-free number, This will give taxpayers the option of toll-free services through the NTA or access to the local TAS office, where they may incur charges. (

) The following are established guidelines for incoming TAS telephone a. LTAs will designate a member or members of their staff to answer telephone calls; b. There shall be no instances when all calls to the LTA office are voice mail/answering machines as normal office procedure. (

) Voice messages will not refer the caller to the NTA toll-free number. page Note: Caution should be taken in leaving answering machine messages involving domestic violence situations or innocent spouse issues. (

) In some cases, it is possible to make a closing contact by voicemail (e.g., involved a simple issue and you have been unable to reach the taxpayer). If the taxpayer is represented, you can never complete the closing contact actions by voicemail. Note: If at all possible, make the closing contact by telephone to utilize the oppor- tunity to further advocate, educate, and address any additional questions or concerns raised by the taxpayer or representative. (

) When calling other IRS employees, and leaving information on an internal voice mail system, do not leave conÔ¨Ådential information. However, it is accept- able to leave non-conÔ¨Ådential information on the system, such as ‚Äúcall me regarding TAMIS case number XXXXXX‚Äù, or similar verbiage. (

) For taxpayer initiated contacts, refer to the Disclosure and Privacy Knowledge Base Site - Cell Phones. TAS is under no obligation to determine if the caller using a less secure platform such as a cell phone or cordless device. What- ever dialogue is necessary, including the disclosure of sensitive but unclassi- Ô¨Åed (SBU) data, is authorized based on the fact the caller has accepted any security vulnerability by contacting TAS using a cordless device. If the TAS ployee knows that the incoming call is on a cell or cordless device, the em- ployee should ask the caller if it is permissible to discuss SBU data considering the communication methodology in use. Such permission should be documented as appropriate. (

) For TAS employees contacting a taxpayer using a cell phone or cordless device, refer to the Disclosure and Privacy Knowledge Base Site - Cell Phones. TAS employees may use a cell phone or cordless device to contact a taxpayer, but no SBU information should be disclosed unless the person con- tacted agrees after being advised the call is being made from a cell phone or cordless device. The taxpayer should also be advised that his/her agreement to use a cell or cordless device is voluntary and that any decision against us- ing the device will have no detrimental effect on the handling of the taxpayer‚Äôs issue. If the taxpayer does not agree, the TAS employee should offer the tax- payer the option of rescheduling the conversation until a more secure ‚Äúland‚Äù line is available. (

) Agreements pertaining to disclosure matters should be completed during the initial contact, if at all possible. TAS employees should document the agreement, as well as whether the agreement pertains to future contacts, in the TAMIS history. (
) ClassiÔ¨Åed information must never be discussed over a cell phone or cordless device.
Note: Caution should be taken in leaving answering machine messages domestic violence situations or innocent spouse issues.

The computerized system of records which houses authorization informa- tion from both Powers of Attorney (POAs) and Tax Information Authorizations (TIAs). The CAF system contains several types of records, among them taxpayer and representative records, tax modules and zations.
Projected date for case resolution communicated to the taxpayer/ representative.
An IRS document identiÔ¨Åed by a number, e.g., Form 1040.
Request for Taxpayer Advocate Service Assistance (And Application for Taxpayer Assistance Order).
An indication of severe consequences for a taxpayer caused by the normal application of IRS regulations and procedures.
The ten-digit number on the front of all SmartID/PAC Cards (formerly Legacy ID).
Research on IDRS or other systems to determine status of case and location for assignment.
An error made on an amended or original return, adjusted or otherwise addressed during processing.
A magnetic tape record which contains taxpayer accounts.

A secure telephone interpreter service, which allows employees to nicate with taxpayers who have limited English proÔ¨Åciency.

Any information which if lost, stolen, misused, or accessed or altered without proper authorization, may adversely affect the national interest or the conduct of federal programs (including IRS operations), or the privacy to which individuals are entitled under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA 5 U.S.C. 552).
Social Security Number
A nine-digit number identifying the account of an individual on the Individual Master File.
Taxpayer Advocate Service

An independent organization within the IRS whose employees assist taxpayers who are experiencing economic harm, who are seeking help in resolving tax problems that have not been resolved through normal channels, or who believe the IRS system or procedure is not working as intended.
Taxpayer Advocate Management Inventory System - An Oracle inventory control and report system used to record, control, and process TAS cases.

A nine-digit number which identiÔ¨Åes the account of an individual or business taxpayer. The TIN may be a Social Security Number, an Individual Taxpayer IdentiÔ¨Åcation Number (ITIN), an Adoption Taxpayer IdentiÔ¨Åcation Number (ATIN), or an Employer IdentiÔ¨Åcation Number (EIN).
